sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: EU members reach a deal on making emergency gas cuts this winter amid fears of an energy crisis if Russia cuts off supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The IMF slashes the global GDP forecast, saying that the outlook looks gloomy and more uncertain.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: and more uncertain.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Here in the Cube, we'll debunk claims that Oxford University is revoking the degrees of thousands of students with links to the Kremlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And at the Euros, it is semi-final time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Is England prepared to take on Sweden?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. It is good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: EU energy ministers have agreed to curb gas use across the bloc in a bid to reduce dependence on Russian supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The decision follows an announcement yesterday by Russian energy giant Gazprom that it will slash natural gas deliveries through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline by 80%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Brussels has asked all 27 member states to reduce consumption by 15% in order to ensure supply throughout the winter. The initiative is voluntary for now, but could become mandatory if Russia cuts supply entirely or if demand is too high. The Czech Republic's Deputy Prime Minister Josef Sikela says that the deal will help to ensure a safe winter ahead. Today we are sending a strong signal, not only to Vladimir Putin, who once again failed to divide the European Union, but most importantly to our citizens.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Today's decision ensures we will not have to face dramatic consequences in winter, including gas security on the price spikes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, our correspondent Shona Murray is covering the minister's energy meeting there in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: She joins me now. Shona, after this deal was reached, I saw a tweet from the EU presidency saying that this was not mission impossible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But there were an awful lot of concerns, I have to say. So how will this work?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Yes, so by and large, the EU has agreed to reduce its gas demand by 15% by each member state. But when you look into the detail, there's been a fair few derogations for certain countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: For example, the island countries like Cyprus, Malta, Ireland, they're completely exempt from it because they're not interconnected with other member states' gas networks. There's also derogations for the Baltic countries, Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, because they're not connected to the European electricity system. And there's potential derogations for countries like Portugal, France and Spain because of their strong gas infrastructure and networks, they could be used to export LNG gas to the rest of Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So the plan initially, as we talked about last week, was supposed to save 45 billion cubic metres of gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It'll be less than that because the derogation is around 30.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But the EU is still confident that this is a worthwhile plan because of what we've seen lately with Putin and Russia gradually but very much reducing the amount of gas being sent to Europe so it's still a strong important measure despite the derogations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So what will this then mean for consumers and of course I'm including everyone using energy in that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Because can Europe essentially survive this winter, this year with less or even with no Russian gas altogether?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, the plan is really to is to take for granted that there will be a complete shutdown of Russian gas throughout Europe. That's the idea. I mean, that's what the expectation is. And that's what this plan is to mitigate for.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But there's a few things we don't know, mainly how cold is it going to be this winter. The EU believes that with this plan in place and with the ability to get new LNG gas from Canada, the United States, Azerbaijan, which has doubled its productivity to the European Union, Norway and other countries, that they'll definitely safely get through this winter, even if it is a cold winter. But it's up to each member state to decide how to reduce the demand as well. But there's also derogations for critical industries like hospitals and certain other industries. But it does remain to be seen how it'll impact on the average consumer and we'll have to look at some of those factors as the weeks and months roll on into winter all right covering the story for us from Brussels our correspondent Shona Murray there shown a good to talk to you thank you well the European Council has also

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: agreed to renew its growing list of sanctions against Russia for another six months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All measures previously adopted by the EU will be extended until the end of January 2023.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, the sanctions date back to 2014.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: They were significantly expanded after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and they consist of a broad range of measures, including personal sanctions against Kremlin officials and restrictions on Russia's finance energy and technology sectors well Russia is

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: continuing to launch missile strikes at targets on Ukraine's Black Sea coast that is despite the warring countries agreeing a breakthrough deal on grain exports from the region among the areas hit was the resort town of Dakota located west of the port city of Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, in Kharkiv, rescuers are continuing to search the rubble for survivors after an airstrike on an arts centre there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And in signs of further divisions between Russia and the West, the Kremlin says that it will leave the International Space Station after 2024.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia has worked alongside international partners on the ISS since its launch in 1998.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But Moscow's new space chief says they'll now aim to create their own orbital station.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Thomas Blade has the latest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The International Space Station once represented a new hope for the world after the Cold War.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But Russia now says it will quit the outpost amid tensions with the West over Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. Yuri Borisov, the chief of Russia's space agency, says his country will leave the International Space Station after 2024.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I think that by this time we will start putting together a Russian orbital station.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The space industry is in a difficult situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I view my main goal, along with my colleagues, as not dropping but instead raising the bar, most of all to provide the Russian economy with the necessary space services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Orbiting 250 miles from Earth, the International Space Station is jointly run by the space agencies of Russia, the US, Europe, Japan and Canada. Its crew researches zero gravity and tests equipment for future space journeys. Thomas Blade, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Gloomy and uncertain, that's the International Monetary Fund's forecast for the global economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Ben Turner has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The International Monetary Fund is issuing a gloomy outlook as it slashes global growth forecasts for 2022 and 2023.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Experts say the world's three biggest economies, the US, China and the Eurozone, are faltering and facing higher inflation rates than previously forecast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The global economy is still reeling from the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We're now facing a gloomy and uncertain outlook. Global output growth has been revised downwards to 3.2% this year and 2.9% next year, while inflation has been revised upwards to 6.6% in advanced economies and 9.5% in emerging and developing economies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The world's three largest economies, the U.S., China and Europe, are stalling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Russia's war with Ukraine has already impacted economies around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: War with Ukraine has already impacted economies around the world. A grain export deal was reached in recent days between Kyiv and Moscow in an attempt to prevent a global food crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ben Turner, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The cost of living crisis was at the heart of last night's debate between two candidates vying to become the head of the UK's Conservative Party and in turn the country's next Prime Minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now in a televised debate, Foreign Secretary Liz Truss and former Treasury Chief Rishi Sunak clashed over taxes, inflation and the UK's relationship with China.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: with China. Now in August, the country's 180,000 Conservative Party members will cast their vote for one of the two, with the results being released on the 5th of September.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Reporting from London for us is Taig Enright. Good evening to you, Taig. Good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This leadership debate last night has kind of been billed as the fiercest clash yet between the two candidates. They've got another one coming up tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But what were your key takeaways from what we saw last night?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Yeah, another one tonight and another one later this week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Helena, the candidates were certainly not holding back on criticising each other.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It was hot-tempered, it was tempestuous.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And even though there were these appeals from many within the Conservative Party, grandees of the Conservative Party, for an end, a cessation, a ceasefire of these so-called blue-on-blue attacks, the two candidates didn't listen, no matter what damage they were doing to the Conservative Party's brand, as some people would have seen it, or indeed to the reputation of the government in which one remains a member and one was a member just up until a few weeks ago. As you say it was the economy and the cost of living crisis which was very much to the fore of this battle of ideas they turned it into a battle of conservative economic principles. The frontrunner Liz Truss calling for immediate tax cuts, saying that that is what conservatism is all about.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Her challenger Rishi Sunak, the former finance minister, saying that tax cuts now simply cannot be afforded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They would have to be funded by borrowing and that they would add further fuel to the fire, that is the cost of living crisis through inflation at this moment in time. He described that as un-conservative.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now the reason the battle lines are being drawn in this way is that this is not a battle for the heart and soul of the general British public but purely for the estimated 160,000 or so members, signed up members of the Conservative Party. They are the people who are picking between these two candidates to become the leader of the ruling Conservative Party and therefore the next Prime Minister of the UK. And that's why we might have been hearing them saying the kind of things that appeals to those Conservative Party members, people who skew predominantly older, middle class, white, rather than things that appeal to the general public in general.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Liz Truss is the frontrunner in terms of opinion polls when it comes to those Conservative party members.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Rishi Sunak is more of a frontrunner when it comes to the general opinion of the public at large.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So the question now is who those members are going to choose.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Someone who does the kind of things that they like in the Here and now or someone who's more likely to build a consensus across the political divide and could help win the Conservatives the next general election All right, I will talking about Boris Johnson for a second He sought to clarify a meeting which he had with the former KGB agent Alexander Lebedev in 2018 now saying this is a quote As far as I'm aware aware no government business was discussed without ease concerns do you think I think that's doubtful Helena there has always been a murkiness to this meeting which happened a good few years ago now at this stage although only very recently in the last few weeks confirmed by Boris Johnson just before his resignation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Even though it was widely reported at the time that Johnson had attended a party at a villa belonging to the Lebedevs in Italy, he was even pictured at the airport heading home by some British holidaymakers, reportedly looking a little dishevelled and hungover.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now we're getting new details clarified by Boris Johnson in a letter to a committee of MPs clarifying the details that he offered to that same committee a few weeks ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That key line, no government business was discussed as far as I'm aware. Well it certainly does raise questions as to who else would have been aware as to what exactly was discussed because he was unaccompanied by any officials, even though he was the foreign minister at the time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It was, he said, a social event.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it does raise another question, whether a friendly meeting with a former KGB agent is any better than a business meeting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, Alexander Lebedev is no ordinary oligarch or even ex-KGB agent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: His son is Evgeny Lebedev, the owner of a very prominent newspaper here in London, The Evening Standard, somebody Boris Johnson would have cultivated a friendship with at a time when he was the mayor of London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And subsequently, he awarded him a seat in the House of Lords.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, Boris Johnson's trying to point the finger at other Labour MPs in this letter who also had links with Lebedev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Really, it does further tarnish Johnson's reputation, but, of course, at a time when he's on his way out the door anyway, so some would say it's a little bit academic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All right, Ty, again, right there, reporting from London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Ty, thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, still to come, the European Union has approved a smallpox vaccine for use against monkeypox. We'll be checking in with a doctor after the break to get you up to date with everything you need to know. Welcome back to the program good to have you with us. The growing number of new monkeypox cases across Europe is

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: sparking concern with the World Health Organization warning that the risk of infection on the continent is high. Now the European Union has approved a smallpox vaccine for use against the disease. In France where about 1,700 people have been infected with the virus, authorities have opened more than 100 vaccination centers. France is just one of nearly 70 countries with confirmed monkeypox outbreaks where the disease was not originally endemic a global spread that the World Health Organization says represents a global health emergency just under 10,000 cases have been reported in the European Union as a whole well joining me now is dr. Barrett

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Pankania senior clinical lecturer at the University of Exeter Medical School great to have you with us doctor now we saw at the weekend of Exeter Medical School. Great to have you with us doctor. Now we saw at the weekend that W.H.O. went ahead. They declared monkeypox a public health emergency of international concern. How worried should we be. I think with monkeypox we can control it maintain it and eliminate it. So whilst the W.H.O. has declared it as a public health emergency of international concern. My view is yes. OK. That is a call to action. But the actions that we can take provided we take these actions fast early and extensively we can't control it manage it and remove it from human circulation. If we don't remove it from human circulation, my concerns are if it becomes present in the animal population, then we've got a problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So we've got the actions which no doubt public health authorities will be taking in terms of contact tracing and so on. But what about protecting ourselves? What can we do? Because right now we're seeing vaccines being approved for use in Europe. Should we ourselves be seeking to get vaccinated. No not at all. So people in the at risk groups will be offered the vaccines. And that is correct. So it's at risk. I mean people men who have sex with men men who are bisexual as well as health care workers and also contacts of those cases. So at the moment we need to do targeted vaccines rather than vaccinate everyone. And by the way people who are aged over 50 will have some immunity from the days when they were immunized against smallpox all those years ago. And if someone thinks that they may have been in contact with someone who potentially has monkeypox, they think that they might be infected, what should they do?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, the first thing is don't go and make a few more cases of your own.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So you will isolate yourself, pick up the phone and call your doctor and discuss this with your doctor.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Do not turn up at the local A&E or your doctor's surgery.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Best to go home and then call your doctor from your home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All right, crystal clear advice there from Dr. Bharat Pankania, Senior Clinical Lecturer at the University of Exeter Medical School in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: As ever, thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, it is crunch time at the Women's European Championships as England's lionesses take on Sweden in the first semi-final tie of the competition. England coming into the fixture on the back of an impressive quarter-final victory against Spain but the players will be all too aware of their worrying track record of three semi-final defeats in seven years. Now Sweden beat Belgium by one goal to nil in their quarterfinal game despite a below par performance from Europe's top ranked team. They'll be hoping to take one step closer to their first final since the Tokyo Olympic Games in 2020. So can the lionesses in their semifinal end their semifinal curse or will the Swedes prove too tough a challenge. Well to give us his thoughts we're joined now by sports reporter Michael Kern. Michael I have to say it is a bit of

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: a mouth-watering tie because we've got England they've kind of got a point to prove here I guess and we've got big expectations from the Swedish side so how do you see this one going? Do you know what it's going to be incredibly close for sure the atmosphere is going to be electric inside Bramall Lane and if there's anything to go by the atmosphere sure. The atmosphere is going to be electric inside Bramall Lane.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And if there's anything to go by the atmosphere in that quarterfinal match for England as well, it's going to be pretty special.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: As you mentioned, they were on the ropes about six minutes from elimination for Ella Toon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Obviously, levelled things up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And then Georgie Stanway went on to score that winner.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The atmosphere on that night was absolutely incredible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Their boss, Sabrina Wigman, has told press that this England team are ready to play their best game they can against Sweden and want to inspire their nation. As you said, that semi-final curse, can they get through that? Well, of course, you mentioned as well Sweden, top-ranked European team. The last time they won a trophy was in 1984 in the Euros. They beat England on penalties after that game finish level after two legs. So I know traditionally England like a penalty shootout.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I think the fans inside the stadium tonight from an England perspective would like it all done in 90 minutes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But either way, it's going to be a tough test for both of these sides who have had a good Euro so far.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Sweden there, quarterfinal, they weren't as convincing as they'd hoped to have been.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But for them, statistically, they had 33 shots on target.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They only managed to put one in the back of the net.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But they are dangerous. They will create chances.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So if anyone's got a ticket and going to that game tonight, they're going to be very much in for a treat.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And who's going to come out on top, we'll have to wait and see.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Not committing there, I see, Michael. So the winner of this tie will face either Germany or France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: How are these sides looking at this stage?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For Germany, they've won eight of the 12 European Women's Championships.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They're the only team yet to concede a goal in the whole competition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They've beaten Denmark, Sweden, Finland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Of course, they had Austria in the quarterfinals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They've scored 11 goals and haven't conceded one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So, of course, Germany are incredibly dangerous.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They're in great form for this one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Third-ranked team, France, that's who they're taking on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They've never won a big trophy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They ended their quarterfinal curse, a bit like we were talking there about England, their semifinal curse.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For the Blues, they've gone out in the past five major tournaments in the quarterfinal stage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So they've been pleased to get through to a semifinal for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Like Sweden as well, they had 33 chances in their last game, France, only scoring one goal. They were lively in the first half and obviously they got their winner in extra time there. But, you know, I think we've got four teams here in these semi-finals that are, you know, very deserving winners if they can go all the way. So hopefully we're going to have some great games of football in both of these semi-finals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Looking forward to it. Sports reporter there, Michael Kern. Good to talk to you, Michael.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, plenty more coming up after a short break. Do stay with us if you can.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight. Welcome back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A Russian state TV channel has claimed that Oxford University is revoking the degrees of 10,000 students with links to the Kremlin and that British police are already destroying the diplomas. A bizarre example of fake news, but where did it come from?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, our team in the Cube has been looking into it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, Helena, social media users as well as Russian state TV have been spreading disinformation that the University of Oxford will be revoking 10,000 diplomas of children of Russian officials and that the administration will not be refunding the tuition fees, much to the horror of certain social media users.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And so the article also includes a quote from the supposed vice-chancellor of Oxford, Sir Louis Lawrence, who claims that the university cannot issue diplomas to people from authoritarian regimes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But we had a quick look at the official university website, and we found that this person does not exist.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: What we did find is that we traced this article to Panorama, which is a Russian website, and it is actually a satirical newspaper, and each article has a disclaimer that these stories are fake.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: However, this did not stop Rossiya One TV channel, which is the biggest state media in Russia, to pick up the story. And Dmitry Kisilov, who is one of the star presenters of the channel, was discussing Western sanctions when he brought up this story about Oxford.
